stories.text: A while ago (maybe 3-4 years ago) someone made a post that showed a large map where a chemist noted all possible ways to transform a family of chemicals into each other. The post was made to showcase the impressive amount of complexity in the world and in other fields that we might not be aware of. Does anyone know what I'm looking for?
stories.title: Ask HN: HN-Post of two large maps showing chemical transformations
Breaking the Monolith at Twitch: Part One

stories.text:
I have a packing problem. I have a 5 packages, that I want to fit in one big box to ship. The big box is priced per unit volume.

Is there a formula or algorithm to find the smallest big box that will fit a certain number of smaller packages?

As a sample, here is a sample of 5 packages which i need to get into one cheapest big box:

L x W x H 11.1 x 10.0 x 4.0 9.3 x 6.8 x 4.8 17.0 x 3.3 x 1.7 5.1 x 4.7 x 3.9 17.7 x 11.8 x 2.8

If there is a reusable solution or method to finding the big box size, it would be much appreciated.
stories.title: Ask HN: How do I find the smallest box than can fit x smaller boxes in it?
In-person socialization down, but social media isn’t to blame, researcher says
